channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: On a Trip That Avoids Beijing, Obama’s Eye Remains on China
item.description: Perhaps no country has more to gain from a new Cold War than China, which has historically benefited from periods of conflict between the United States and Russia, analysts say.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama at a state dinner in Malaysia, one of four stops on his Asia tour, with King Abdul Halim and Queen Haminah.

item.title: Afghan Voters Signaling a Turn
item.description: In preliminary results released Saturday, Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai’s and an ardent supporter of the United States, won 45 percent of the votes in the presidential election, but not enough to avoid a runoff.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah at his home in Kabul this week. He won 45 percent of the vote, according to preliminary results.

item.title: Afghan Panel Claims to Find Secret Prisons
item.description: The commission appointed by President Hamid Karzai said it discovered unlawful prisons run by American and British forces.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Obama Opens Long-Awaited Visit to Malaysia
item.description: In the first visit to the country by an American president in nearly half a century, President Obama landed in Kuala Lumpur on Saturday and planned economic and security talks with Prime Minister Najib Razak.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President Obama inspected an honor guard on Saturday during a welcoming ceremony outside the Parliament house in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

item.title: Popes John XXIII and John Paul II to Be Canonized
item.description: John XXIII, revered by Roman Catholic liberals, and John Paul II, beloved by conservatives, will be recognized as saints at a Mass on Sunday as Pope Francis pushes his own vision of a church under a big tent.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Priest students with a picture depicting John Paul II, left, and John XXIII near St. Peter's Square in the Vatican on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Communist Mouthpiece Says it Complained to Twitter About Parody
item.description: People’s Daily, the flagship paper of China’s Communist Party, continued its assault on a Twitter account that parodies the country’s rulers, saying it violates Twitter’s rules.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Australia May Expand Search for Jet
item.description: A search of the area where the missing Malaysia Airlines flight most likely went down is nearly complete, but no wreckage has been found.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Turkish Leader Signs Bill Expanding Spy Agency’s Power
item.description: Turkey’s spy agency will gain broad immunity from prosecution and access to public and private data without court orders.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After ‘Cadmium Rice,’ now ‘Lead’ and ‘Arsenic Rice’
item.description: A study of soil, water and rice grown around a metals smelter in Hunan Province shows high levels of toxic pollutants, adding to a growing body of evidence that China’s soil is badly degraded in many areas.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farmer works her land near a lead smelter in Hunan Province.

item.title: Tensions Mount in Bolivia as Soldiers Protest Career Obstacles
item.description: The military has dismissed 702 low-ranking officers who were protesting to draw attention to the advancement challenges they face in the armed forces.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: U.S. Says It Built Digital Programs Abroad With an Eye to Politics
item.description: The United States built Twitter-like programs in Afghanistan and Pakistan, but like a similar program in Cuba, they were shut down for lack of money, officials said.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON
item.media:description: Rajiv Shah, administrator of the Agency for International Development, testified this month about the agency’s Twitter-like program in Cuba.

item.title: Nigerian Movie Appears to Hit Nerve Over War
item.description: “Half of a Yellow Sun” was scheduled to open in Nigeria on Friday, but the country’s film censorship board has refused to issue the movie a certificate, effectively banning it.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Biyi Bandele, the director of "Half of a Yellow Sun."

item.title: Defying Moscow, Ukraine Threatens to Blockade Pro-Russian Militants
item.description: As tension mounted, the interim authorities said any crossing of the country’s borders by Russian troops would be treated as an invasion.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Building a checkpoint on the outskirts of Slavyansk, Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: European Firms Seek to Minimize Russia Sanctions
item.description: As businesses, particularly in the energy sector, campaign to maintain ties with Moscow, the world’s seven wealthiest nations said on Friday they would impose additional sanctions on Russia resulting from its military action in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: About a quarter of the European Union’s natural gas supplies originate in Russia. Pictured, a border delivery station in eastern Slovakia that distributes gas from Russia into western Europe.

item.title: Xishuangbanna Journal: In Land That Values Ivory, Wild Elephants Find a Safe Haven
item.description: Government protections are helping Asian elephant numbers rise, but forests are rapidly giving way to rubber and other cash crops.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists were carried through Wild Elephant Valley, a nature park outside Jinghong that draws thousands of visitors a day.

item.title: North Korea Says It Detained U.S. Tourist Seeking Shelter There
item.description: The North’s official news agency reported that the American, identified as Miller Matthew Todd, 24, was being held for his “rash behavior” while passing through customs on April 10.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Chen Yizi, a Top Adviser Forced to Flee China, Dies at 73
item.description: Mr. Chen, a close ally of Zhao Ziyang, sought to rally intellectuals and party moderates to support the student protests at Tiananmen Square.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: World Briefing : Ecuador: A U.S. Office Is Closed
item.description: The government of Ecuador has told the United States Embassy to shut down a military cooperation office staffed by about 20 people from the Defense Department, an embassy spokesman said Friday
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing : Qatar: U.S. Couple Seeks Respite
item.description: A Los Angeles couple convicted last month of child endangerment, not the original charge of murder they had faced, in the 2013 death of their adopted daughter will seek permission from an appellate court to go home while their appeal is pending, defense lawyers said this week.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing : Congo: Deadly Stadium Stampede
item.description: More than 20 people were killed Friday in the southwestern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo when generators failed during a festival honoring a popular singer, plunging the stadium into darkness and causing a stampede, officials and witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing : Afghanistan: Floods Kill Dozens
item.description: Over 100 people have been killed and thousands have been left homeless by flash floods in northern and western Afghanistan, officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: A Policy-Making Mystery in the Renminbi’s Decline
item.description: Observers question whether the drop in the value of China’s currency to its lowest levels since 2012 is a result of central bank intervention or a weakening economy.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Theodore Kaye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yan Xiaowei, right, said the weaker renminbi was helping his company’s bottom line.

item.title: Iraqi Militants Stage Political Rally, Then Bombs Go Off
item.description: Bombs killed over 30 at a political rally in Baghdad by a Shiite militant group, Asaib Ahl al-Haq, and the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a Sunni group, claimed responsibility.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: The bombings struck a rally held by a Shiite militant group, Asaib Ahl al-Haq, in the parking lot of an old soccer stadium in Baghdad on Friday.

item.title: Despite Missing Economic Goals, Greece Manages to Meet a Bailout Target
item.description: The European Commission said in a report on Friday that Greece had made enough progress to warrant disbursing 6.3 billion euros that had been held back.

item.title: Russia Raises Rate to Bolster Economy After S.&P. Cuts Its Debt Rating
item.description: The move is intended to help halt a slide in the country’s currency and stem the flight of investment capital from the country.
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and DAVID JOLLY
